questions.question: A 36-year-old woman presented with intermittent suprapubic pain, increased urinaryfrequency, and dysuria for 2 months. A cystoscopy revealed the presence of Hunner ulcers.What is the likely diagnosis?

A 31-year-old man presented with a history of recurrent UTIs and hematuria. Urine cultureshowed growth of E. coli. Flexible cystoscopy revealed yellow-brown soft plaques with acentral umbilication. Microscopy of the plaque showed Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. What isthe likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: This clinical scenario with the presence of Michaelis-Gutmann bodies is suggestive ofmalakoplakia.Malakoplakia is a chronic inflammatory reaction resulting from acquired defects in phagocytefunction, commonly affecting the urinary bladder. It can also be seen in other organ systems likethe gastrointestinal tract, female genital tract, and central nervous system.It is seen in chronic bacterial infection, mostly by Escherichia coli or occasionally Proteusspecies.Grossly, it presents as soft, yellow-brown, slightly raised mucosal plaques. Microscopically, thefollowing findings are seen:848• Large, foamy macrophages containing -• Abundant granular cytoplasm due to undigested bacterial products•Michaelis-Gutmann bodies - PAS-positive basophilic concretions due to iron and calciumdeposits in lysosomes• Occasional multinucleated giant cells and lymphocytesMalakoplakia - Michaelis-Gutmann bodiesaMichaelis-GutmannbodiesNote: Xanthogranulomatous cystitis is morphologically and probably pathogenetically similar tomalakoplakia, but it lacks Michaelis-Gutmann bodies.

questions.question: What is the most common cause of polypoid cystitis?
questions.explanation: The most common cause of polypoid cystitis is indwelling catheters.Polypoid cystitis is an inflammatory lesion resulting from mucosal irritation. It may also beassociated with radiation therapy and malignant tumors. It usually involves the posterior wall ofthe bladder.Grossly, it may show bulbous or papillary appearance and may be confused with papillaryurothelial carcinoma. Microscopically, the papillary projections are broad-based, non-branching,and without atypia. Stroma is edematous with minimal inflammation.Options A and D: Adenovirus infection and the use of anti-cancer drugs like cyclophosphamidecause hemorrhagic cystitis.Option B: Systemic allergic disorders cause eosinophilic cystitis.

questions.question: 844A pathologist observed a metaplastic lesion in a biopsy sample taken from the bladdermucosa of a patient. Which of the following is not a differential diagnosis?
questions.explanation: 849Malakoplakia is not a metaplastic lesion of the bladder. It is a type of chronic granulomatouscystitis due to defective phagocytic function that may mimic malignancy.Metaplastic lesions of the bladder include the following:• Nests of urothelium (Brunn nests) may grow downward into the lamina propria resulting in thefollowing lesions -• Cystitis glandularis - epithelial cells in the center of the nest undergo metaplasia and take on acuboidal or columnar appearance••Cystitis cystica - epithelial cells retract to produce cystic spaces lined by flattened urotheliumSquamous metaplasia - in response to injury, urothelium is replaced by stratified squamousepithelium.•Nephrogenic adenoma - due to implantation of shed renal tubular cells at sites of injuredurothelium, resulting in replacement of urothelium by cuboidal epithelium with a papillarygrowth pattern

questions.question: What is the most common tumor of the urinary bladder?
questions.explanation: The most common tumor of the urinary bladder is transitional cell carcinoma or urothelialcarcinoma.Other epithelial tumors like squamous cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma, and small cell carcinomamay also occur.Sarcomas are distinctly uncommon in the bladder. However, the most common sarcoma ininfancy or childhood is embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, and the most common sarcoma in thebladder in adults is leiomyosarcoma.

questions.question: A 57-year-old man presented with chronic hematuria and dysuria. Microscopic examinationof urine showed the following parasitic eggs. What type of bladder carcinoma is commonlyassociated with this condition?
questions.explanation: The image shows oval-shaped eggs with the terminal spine which is characteristic of Schistosomahaematobium. It is most commonly associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.The ova are deposited in the bladder wall and incite a brisk chronic inflammatory response. Thisinduces progressive mucosal squamous metaplasia and dysplasia and, in some instances,neoplasia.Schistosomal infection can less frequently result in adenocarcinoma or transitional cellcarcinoma.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a carcinogen for bladder cancer?
questions.explanation: Isopropyl alcohol is not implicated in the causation of bladder cancer.Benzidine, arylamines, and phenacetin are well-established risk factors for bladder cancer.850

questions.question: Which of the following genetic changes is not associated with bladder carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Activating mutation in HRAS (not NRAS) is responsible for bladder carcinoma.Genetic changes associated with carcinoma bladder:•Noninvasive low-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma is associated with:• Gain-of-function mutations of FGFR3 and HRAS genes•Chromosome 9p and 9q deletions⚫ High-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma (either papillary or flat) is associated with:•⚫ Loss-of-function mutations of TP53 and RB genesNote: Erdafitinib (kinase inhibitor) is the first targeted drug therapy approved by the FDA for thetreatment of metastatic urothelial carcinoma especially in patients with mutations of FGFR3 orFGFR2.

questions.question: The most consistent and persistent feature of bladder carcinoma is:
questions.explanation: The most consistent and persistent feature of carcinoma bladder is painless hematuria.Bladder tumors produce a wide range of clinical features including:• Painless hematuria - classical feature and may be the only clinical manifestation•⚫ Irritative urinary symptoms (frequency, urgency, dysuria) - diffuse tumors or tumors at thebladder neck•Pyelonephritis or hydronephrosis - when the ureteral orifice is involved•⚫ Obstructive symptoms, palpable suprapubic mass, or lower extremity edema - latepresentation with a large tumor mass•Weight loss and/or localized bone pain - metastatic disease

questions.question: Which of the following is not included in the latest International Society of UrologicalPathology grading of urothelial tumors?

options.B: Urothelial neoplasm of low malignant potential846

questions.explanation: International Society of Urological Pathology (ISUP) grading system classifies papillary urothelialcarcinoma into 2 grades - low grade and high grade. The classification of papillary urothelialcarcinoma into grades 1, 2, 3 was was part of the earlier WHO classification.Grading of urothelial (transitional cell) tumors:WHO/ISUP grades:•Urothelial papilloma•• Urothelial neoplasm of low malignant potential851••Papillary urothelial carcinoma, low gradePapillary urothelial carcinoma, high gradeWHO grades (old classification):• Urothelial papilloma• Urothelial neoplasm of low malignant potential•••Papillary urothelial carcinoma, grade 1Papillary urothelial carcinoma, grade 2• Papillary urothelial carcinoma, grade 3

questions.question: A 67-year-old chronic smoker with gross painless hematuria was diagnosed with infiltratingurothelial carcinoma. What is the most important prognostic factor for his condition?
questions.explanation: The staging (extent of spread) at the time of initial diagnosis is the most important prognosticfactor in infiltrating urothelial carcinoma.The prognosis of bladder carcinoma depends on the histologic grade and the stage at diagnosis. Asmost infiltrating urothelial carcinomas are high-grade, staging becomes the major factor todetermine the prognosis.852
